message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful ulceration, discharge, and breast enlargement with skin thickening and edema, suggest inflammatory breast cancer. The family history of breast cancer also increases the likelihood of cancer. The mammography and pathology report further support this diagnosis, as dermal lymphatic invasion is a hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer. Lobular carcinoma in situ would not present with ulceration, and infiltrating lobular and ductal carcinomas may have similar symptoms but do not typically present with lymphatic invasion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of inflammatory breast cancer, which is characterized by enlarged, firm breasts with thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and nipple retraction or discharge. The family history of breast cancer also increases the likelihood of cancer. The mammography findings and pathology report confirm the diagnosis. Lobular carcinoma in situ is not associated with ulceration or discharge. Infiltrating lobular and ductal carcinomas may have similar presentations, but dermal lymphatic invasion is more common in inflammatory breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits many signs of inflammatory breast cancer, including breast enlargement, thickened skin, erythema, and tenderness, as well as an ulcer and nipple discharge. The family history of breast cancer also suggests high risk. The mammography and biopsy results confirm the diagnosis of invasive breast cancer with dermal lymphatic invasion. Lobular carcinoma in situ typically does not present with skin changes or lymph node involvement. Infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma can both cause skin changes and lymph node involvement, but the rapid onset and severity of symptoms suggest inflammatory breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of an ulcer, discharge, firmness, thickened skin, and edema, along with lymphatic invasion, suggest inflammatory breast cancer. LCIS does not present with an ulcer, and infiltrating lobular and ductal carcinomas do not usually present with diffuse erythema and edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms point towards inflammatory breast cancer, which is a rare but aggressive subtype of breast cancer that presents with erythema, edema, and ulceration. The presence of lymphatic invasion in the pathology report confirms this diagnosis. Lobular carcinoma in situ is a non-invasive subtype, while infiltrating lobular and ductal carcinoma do not typically present with the same symptoms as inflammatory breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful ulceration, discharge from the nipple, and a family history of breast cancer, and the results of mammography and pathology report suggest inflammatory breast cancer. Lobular carcinoma in situ and infiltrating lobular carcinoma may present with breast enlargement and thickening, but not with the characteristic ulceration and erythema. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma may cause nipple discharge, but usually not with ulceration and erythema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with inflammatory breast cancer, including painful ulceration, discharge from nipple, edema, erythema, and axillary adenopathy. The mammography findings and pathology report also point towards inflammatory breast cancer. Lobular and infiltrating lobular carcinoma usually do not cause ulcers and are not associated with lymphatic invasion, while infiltrating ductal carcinoma can cause ulcers but is not associated with lymphatic invasion at an early stage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of painful ulceration with an increasing size of the breast, thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and nipple discharge suggest inflammatory breast cancer, which is characterized by rapid onset of inflammation and is also associated with lymphatic invasion. The patient’s family history and imaging findings also support the diagnosis. Lobular carcinoma in situ does not typically present with ulceration or erythema, and is not associated with lymphatic invasion. Invasive lobular carcinoma is commonly palpable and does not present with rapid inflammation as in the case presented. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma may present with nipple discharge and adenopathy, but typically lacks the rapid onset of inflammation and ulceration seen in inflammatory breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including painful ulceration, discharge, thickened skin, erythema, edema, and adenopathy, are consistent with inflammatory breast cancer (IBC). The presence of a mass with calcifications, parenchymal distortion, and dermal lymphatic invasion are also supporting factors for an IBC diagnosis. LCIS typically does not present with palpable masses or skin changes, and is usually an incidental finding on mammography or biopsy. Infiltrating lobular carcinoma (ILC) is less likely to cause skin changes and inflammatory symptoms, and is typically detected on imaging or physical examination as a subtle thickening or subtle mass. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma (IDC) can also present with skin changes and inflammatory symptoms, but these are less common than in IBC. However, without additional information about the pathology and imaging findings, it is possible that ILC or IDC could also be present.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, physical examination findings, and mammography all suggest Inflammatory breast cancer. The clear dermal lymphatic invasion by tumor cells confirms the diagnosis. Lobular carcinoma in situ is a noninvasive condition, while infiltrating lobular and ductal carcinoma may cause thickening and distortion on mammography, but the clinical presentation and characteristic skin changes are not present.
